case_name: Express Newspapers Limited v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 596 of 1963 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 596 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment dated March 1, 1960 of Madras High Court in Case Referred No. 11 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment dated March 1, 1960 of the Madras High Court in Case Referred No. 11 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on May 7, 1964 by SUBBA RAO, J.

anchor.surface_text: N. Rajagopal Sastri and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant. Ganapathy Iyer and R. Gopalakrishnan, for the respondent. May 7, 1964 The Judgment of the Court was deliv

facts.text: Appeal by special leave against order of Madras High Court in reference under S. 66(1) of Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is preferred against the order of the Madras High Court in a reference made to it by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under S. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: Free Press of India Madras Ltd. was a private limited company carrying on business as printers and publishers of newspapers: Indian Express, Dinamani, Andhra Prabha at Madras, Eastern Express and Bharat at Calcutta, Sunday Standard and Morning Standard at Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The Free Press of India  Madras  Ltd., hereinafter called the Free Press Company, was a private limited companypany carrying on business as printers and publishers of certain newspapers, namely, Indian Express, Dhinamani and Andhra Prabha at Madras, Eastern Express and Bharat at Calcutta and Sunday Standard and Morning Standard at Bombay.

facts.text: Express Newspapers Limited (assessee-company) formed on or about April 22, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: transferring to the -Express Newspapers Limited, a new companypany formed on or about April 22, 1946, hereinafter called the assessee-company,

facts.text: On August 31, 1946, Free Press Company passed resolution transferring right to print and publish newspapers to assessee-company from September 1, 1946, letting out machinery and assets, authorizing collection of book debts and payment of liabilities.

anchor.surface_text: On August 31, 1946, the Free Press Company passed a resolution transferring to the -Express Newspapers Limited, a new companypany formed on or about April 22, 1946, hereinafter called the assessee-company, the right to print and publish the said newspapers from September 1. 1946. letting out its machinery and assets and authorizing the assessee-company to companylect the book debts and pay off the liabilities of the Free Press Company.

facts.text: Assessee-company started publishing newspapers from September 1, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee companypany accordingly started publishing newspapers from September 1, 1946.

facts.text: On October 31, 1946, Free Press Company resolved at General Body Meeting to wind up voluntarily; liquidator directed to carry on business.

anchor.surface_text: On October 31, 1946, the Free Press Company resolved at a General Body Meeting to wind up the companypany voluntarily. The liquidator appointed thereunder was directed number to carry on the business of the companypany.

facts.text: On November 1, 1946, liquidator ascertained value of assets over liabilities taken over by assessee-company as Rs. 19,36,000 credited to account of two directors of Free Press Company in assessee's books.

anchor.surface_text: On November 1, 1946, the liquidator ascertained the value of the assets over the liabilities taken over by the assessee-company as per the balance-sheet at Rs. 19,36.000/and this amount was credited to the account of the two directors of the Free Press Company in the assessees books.

facts.text: Profit of Free Press Company worked out to Rs. 6,08,666 as difference between written down value and sale price of machinery.

anchor.surface_text: The profit of the Free Press Company was worked out to be Rs. 6,08,666, being the difference between the written down value and the sale price of the machinery.

facts.text: Profit comprised: (i) difference between original cost and written down value: Rs. 2,14,090; (ii) excess over original cost: Rs. 3,94,576.

anchor.surface_text: That sum was made up of,  i  the difference between the original companyt price and the written down price of the machinery. Rs. 2,14,090/-,  ii  the amount in excess over the original companyt price Rs. 3,94,576/-.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer included Rs. 2,14,090 as profit under proviso to s.10(2)(vii) and Rs. 3,94,576 as capital gains under s.12B in assessee's total income and assessed to tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer included the said two items in the total income of the assessee companypany under the following heads,  i  profit under proviso to s. 10 2   vii  Rs. 2,14,090/-, and  ii  capital gains under s. 12B Rs. 3,94,576/-, and assessed each to tax.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld inclusion of capital gains item but rejected inclusion of first item (Rs. 2,14,090).

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld the validity of the inclusion of the item under capital gains in the total income of the assessee but decided against the inclusion of the first item.

facts.text: Tribunal referred questions to Madras High Court under s.66(1): (1) Whether Free Press made business profit of Rs.2,14,090 under proviso to s.10(2)(vii)? (2) Whether capital gain by Free Press assessable in hands of Express under s.26(2)?

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal referred the following two questions, among others, for the decision of the High Court of Madras under s. 66 1  of the Incometax Act- Whether Free Press Company made a business profit of Rs. 2,14,090/- under proviso to section 10 2  vii  of the Act? Whether the capital gain made by the Free Press Company is liable to be assessed in the hands of the Express Company, under section 26 2  of the Act?

facts.text: Madras High Court Division Bench (Rajagopalan and Ramachandra Iyer JJ) answered both questions in negative against department.

anchor.surface_text: The reference was heard by a Division Bench of the High Court, companysisting of Rajagopalan and Ramachandra Iyer, JJ., who by their judgment answered the two questions in the negative and against the department.

facts.text: During accounting year 1946-47, Free Press Company did not do business of printing/publishing from September 1, 1946; assessee-company carried it on thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: During the accounting year 1946-47 the Free Press Company did number do the business of printing and publishing newspapers from September 1, 1946, and thereafter the assessee-company alone was carrying on the said business.

facts.text: Free Press Company went into voluntary liquidation on October 31, 1946; liquidator confirmed transfer of assets to assessee on November 1, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The Free Press Company went into voluntary liquidation on October 31, 1946, and the liquidator, on November 1, 1946, companyfirmed the transfer of the assets made by the Free Press Company to the assessee-company.

facts.text: On November 1, 1946, machinery sold yielding profit of Rs.6,08,666 to Free Press Company (difference between WDV and sale price).

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, on November 1, 1946, the aforesaid machinery was sold yielding a profit of Rs. 6,08,666/- to the Free Press Company being the difference between the written down value and the sale price of the machinery.

facts.text: Machinery sold by Free Press Company during accounting year after closing business and during voluntary liquidation.

anchor.surface_text: Broadly stated, the machinery was sold by the Free Press Company during the accounting year after it closed down its business and after it went into voluntary liquidation.

facts.text: Revenue contended Rs.2,14,090 assessable under proviso to s.10(2)(vii).

anchor.surface_text: The first item of Rs. 2,14,090/-, representing the surplus over the written down value of the machinery was assessable in accordance with the proviso to s. 10  2   vii  --of the Act

facts.text: Revenue contended Rs.3,94,576 capital gains assessable in hands of assessee under s.26(2).

anchor.surface_text: the second item of Rs. 3,94,576/-, representing the capital gains made by the Free Press Company is assessable in the hands of the assessee- companypany, who succeeded to the said business, under s. 26 2  of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court held first item not liable to tax under proviso to s.10(2)(vii).

anchor.surface_text: For the fore- going reasons we hold that the first item is number liable to tax and the High Court has given the companyrect answer to the first question submitted to it.

facts.text: Supreme Court agreed with High Court that capital gains not assessable in hands of assessee under s.26(2).

anchor.surface_text: In the result we agree with the High Court in regard to the answer it has given in respect of the second question.
This appeal by special leave is preferred against the order
under S. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, hereinafter called the Act.

issues.text: Whether Free Press Company made a business profit of Rs. 2,14,090/- under proviso to section 10 2  vii  of the Act?

arguments.claim: The first item of Rs. 2,14,090/-, representing the surplus over the written down value of the machinery was assessable in accordance with the proviso to s. 10(2)(vii) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: 1  The first item of Rs. 2,14,090/-, representing the surplus over the written down value of the machinery was assessable in accordance with the proviso to s. 10  2   vii  --of the Act and

court_response_anchor.surface_text: mber been allowed that amount would have swelled the profits to that extent. When it is found that it was wrongly allowed that profit is brought to ch

arguments.court_reasoning: Proviso applies only if business carried on during accounting year, machinery used in business, and sold while business ongoing, not during winding up; here sale after business closed and in liquidation

arguments.claim: The second item of Rs. 3,94,576/-, representing the capital gains made by the Free Press Company is assessable in the hands of the assessee-company, who succeeded to the said business, under s. 26(2) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: 2  the second item of Rs. 3,94,576/-, representing the capital gains made by the Free Press Company is assessable in the hands of the assessee- companypany, who succeeded to the said business, under s. 26 2  of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.26(2) applies only to business profits under 4th head of s.6, not capital gains which is separate 6th head; mutually exclusive heads; fiction in s.12B limited

arguments.claim: Neither the conditions laid down in s. 10(2)(vii) of the Act nor those laid down in s. 26(2) thereof attracted the said two items of income and therefore they were not assessable in the hands of the assessee-company

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondent contended that neither the conditions laid down in s. 10 2  vii  of the Act nor those laid down in s. 26 2  thereof attracted the said two items of income and, therefore, they were not assessable

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed with High Court on both questions

arguments.claim: Tax under s.10 is payable in respect of profits or gains of business carried on by assessee during accounting year

anchor.surface_text: Section 10.- 1  The tax shall be payable by an assessee under the head Profits and gains of business, profession or vocation in respect of the profit or gains of any business, profession or vocation carried on by him.

arguments.claim: Proviso to s.10(2)(vii) brings to charge escaped profit from excess depreciation on machinery used in business sold while business carried on

anchor.surface_text: the difference between the original cost and the written down value shall be deemed to be profits of the previous year in which the sale took place that is to say, the difference between the price fetched at the sale and the written down value is deemed to be the escaped profits

arguments.claim: Conditions for proviso: (1) business carried on during previous year, (2) machinery used in business, (3) sold when business being carried on not for winding up

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, to bring the sale proceeds to charge the following conditions shall be fulfilled 1 During the entire previous year or a part of it the business shall have been carried on by the assessee 2 the machinery shall have been used in the business and 3 the machinery shall have been sold when the business was being carried on

arguments.claim: In this case, machinery sold after business closed and during winding up, so proviso does not apply

anchor.surface_text: the sale of the machinery in the instant case having taken place after the business was closed and during the winding up proceedings, it would fall outside the scope of the said proviso and therefore the first item is not assessable to tax

arguments.claim: Pursa Limited case holds surplus on sale during winding up not taxable under proviso to s.10(2)(vii)

anchor.surface_text: This Court held that the said amount was not taxable... the sale of the machinery and plant was not an operation in furtherance of the business carried on by the company but was a realisation of its assets in the process of gradual winding up

arguments.claim: National Syndicate applies to substantive clause of s.10(2)(vii) allowing loss after closure, not to proviso

anchor.surface_text: This Court expressly confined the scope of the decision to the substantive part of cl. vii without disturbing the validity of the decisions governing the second proviso... it is not proper that we should rely upon it in preference to a direct decision on the second proviso

arguments.claim: Winding up sale is not trading or carrying on business (West Coast Chemicals)

anchor.surface_text: held that a winding up sale was not trading or doing business... mere realisation of assets is not trading and that there was distinction between sales forming part of the trading activities and those where the realisation was not an act of trading

arguments.claim: First item not liable to tax under proviso to s.10(2)(vii)

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons we hold that the first item is not liable to tax and the High Court has given the correct answer to the first question submitted to it.

arguments.claim: Heads of income under s.6 mutually exclusive; item under one head not chargeable under another (United Commercial Bank)

anchor.surface_text: This Court in United Commercial Bank Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal laid down that ss. 7 to 12 are mutually exclusive and where an item of income falls specifically under one head it is to be charged under that head and not other.

arguments.claim: s.26(2) applies only to income, profits and gains of business (4th head), not capital gains (6th head)

anchor.surface_text: Section 26 2 indicates the manner of assessment of the income, profits and gains of any business, profession or vocation. This section does not provide for the assessment of income under any other head.

arguments.claim: Deeming provision in s.12B makes capital gains income of previous year but does not convert to business profits

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that a legal fiction is limited to the purpose for which it is created and should not be extended beyond its legitimate field.

arguments.claim: Capital gains losses set off only against capital gains, confirming separate treatment

anchor.surface_text: Sub-sections 2A and 2B of s. 24 provide for the setting off of the loss falling under the head capital gains against any capital gains falling under the same head. Such loss cannot be set off against an income falling under any different head.

arguments.claim: Agree with High Court that capital gain not assessable in hands of assessee under s.26(2)

anchor.surface_text: In the result we agree with the High Court in regard to the answer it has given in respect of the second question.

holdings.text: the first item is not liable to tax and the High Court has given the correct answer to the first question submitted to it

anchor.surface_text: For the fore- going reasons we hold that the first item is number liable to tax and the High Court has given the companyrect answer to the first question submitted to it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to s.10(2)(vii) applies only where business carried on during previous year, machinery used in business, and sold while business ongoing not during winding up; here sale after closure and in liquidation; realisation not trading; Pursa Ltd. and West Coast Chemicals followed, National Syndicate distinguished

holdings.text: the second item representing capital gains is not assessable in the hands of the assessee-company under s.26(2)

anchor.surface_text: In the result we agree with the High Court in regard to the answer it has given in respect of the second question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.26(2) limited to income profits gains of business (4th head s.6), not capital gains (6th head); heads mutually exclusive per United Commercial Bank; s.12B deeming fiction limited, does not convert to business profits; s.24(2A)(2B) confirms separate treatment

holdings.text: To bring the sale proceeds to charge under proviso to s.10(2)(vii) the following conditions shall be fulfilled: 1 During the entire previous year or a part of it the business shall have been carried on by the assessee 2 the machinery shall have been used in the business and 3 the machinery shall have been sold when the business was being carried on and not for the purpose of closing it down or winding it up

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, to bring the sale proceeds to charge the following conditions shall be fulfilled 1 During the entire previous year or a part of it the business shall have been carried on by the assessee 2 the machinery shall have been used in the business and 3 the machinery shall have been sold when the business was being carried on

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.10(1) requiring business carried on; such machinery refers to used in business per cls.(iv)-(vii); proviso brings escaped depreciation only if sale while business ongoing

holdings.text: ss. 7 to 12 are mutually exclusive and where an item of income falls specifically under one head it is to be charged under that head and not other

anchor.surface_text: This Court in United Commercial Bank Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income- tax, West Bengal 1  laid down that ss. 7 to 12 are mutually exclusive and where an item of income falls specifically under one head it is to be charged under that head and not other.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopting United Commercial Bank; s.6 heads distinct; business profits (s.10) separate from capital gains (s.12B); s.26(2) only for business head

holdings.text: Section 26(2) indicates the manner of assessment of the income, profits and gains of any business, profession or vocation. This section does not provide for the assessment of income under any other head

anchor.surface_text: Section 26 2 indicates the manner of assessment of the income, profits and gains of any business, profession or vocation. This section does number provide for the assessment of income under any other head.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading; limited to 4th head s.6; income profits gains term covers business head only in context; proviso same; excludes capital gains

holdings.text: a legal fiction is limited to the purpose for which it is created and should not be extended beyond its legitimate field

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that a legal fiction is limited to the purpose for which it is created and should number be extended beyond its legitimate field.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.12B deems capital gains income of previous year but does not place under business head or make business profits

precedents.citation: The Liquidators of Pursa Limited v. Commissioner of Incometax, Bihar 1

anchor.surface_text: This point directly arose for companysideration in The Liquidators of Pursa Limited v. Commissioner of Incometax, Bihar 1 . There, the assessee-company carried on the business of growing sugarcane and manufacturing and selling sugar.

precedents.case_name: Liquidators of Pursa Limited v Commissioner of Income-tax Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: surplus on sale of machinery and plant after business closed down and during winding up not taxable under proviso 2 to s.10(2)(vii)
precedents.cited_holding: sale was not in furtherance of business but realisation of assets in winding up; machinery not used in accounting year

precedents.citation: The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay Circle II v. The National Syndicate, Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: This question again fell to be companysidered by this Court in The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay Circle II v. The National Syndicate, Bombay 1 . There, the National Syndicate, a Bombay firm, acquired on January 11, 1945, a tailoring business as a going companycern for Rs. 89,321/-

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay Circle II v National Syndicate Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: loss on sale of machinery after business closed down allowable under s.10(2)(vii) substantive clause if used in part of accounting year
precedents.cited_holding: principles governing proviso do not apply to main clause

precedents.citation: K. M. S. Reddy, Commissioner of Income-tax, Kerala v. The West Coast Chemicals and Industries Ltd. in liquidation , Alleppy 2

anchor.surface_text: This Court in K. M. S. Reddy, Commissioner of Income-tax, Kerala v. The West Coast Chemicals and Industries Ltd. in liquidation , Alleppy 2  held that a winding up sale was number trading or doing business.

precedents.case_name: K M S Reddy Commissioner of Income-tax Kerala v West Coast Chemicals and Industries Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: sale of assets in winding up is not carrying on business or trading
precedents.cited_holding: realisation of assets and raw materials after winding up not sale in course of business

precedents.citation: United Commercial Bank Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income- tax, West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court in United Commercial Bank Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income- tax, West Bengal 1  laid down that ss. 7 to 12 are mutually exclusive and where an item of income falls specifically under one head it is to be charged under that head and numberother.

precedents.case_name: United Commercial Bank Ltd v Commissioner of Income-tax West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: sections 7 to 12 are mutually exclusive heads of income
precedents.cited_holding: item of income charged under specific head, not another

anchor.surface_text: In the result we agree with the High Court in regard to the answer it has given in respect of the second question. In this view numberother question arises for our companysideration.
